content.raw: We could write custom code that would do this conversion, but I'm not sure it can be done with `Converter.cc` in its current form.
content.html: We could write custom code that would do this conversion, but I'm not sure it can be done with Converter.cc in its current form.

pullrequest.title: Update pose frame proposal to support //xyz[@expressed_in]

content.raw:
Hm… If we have custom code, how hard would it be to do the kinematics? \(e.g. get the full frame graph?\)

If it’s not that hard, perhaps we just go that route, and defer introducing this new attribute unless it’s necessary?

Alternative is that I modify `Converter.cc` to always add some crazy \(obfuscated\) model frame name like `model_frame_from_sdf_converter` - if that element already exists, throw an error \(which seems tractable to have [Converter.cc](http://Converter.cc) do\)…
content.html:
Hm… If we have custom code, how hard would it be to do the kinematics? (e.g. get the full frame graph?)

If it’s not that hard, perhaps we just go that route, and defer introducing this new attribute unless it’s necessary?

Alternative is that I modify Converter.cc to always add some crazy (obfuscated) model frame name like model_frame_from_sdf_converter - if that element already exists, throw an error (which seems tractable to have Converter.cc do)…

pullrequest.title: Update pose frame proposal to support //xyz[@expressed_in]

content.raw:
Can we address that `__model__` cannot be used in `//model/pose[@relative_to]`? Also, can the implicit model frame be referred to by its name if the referring entity is at the same level as the model? For example, is the following allowed?

```

<world name='w'>
  <model name='M1'/>
  <model name='M2'>
    <pose relative_to='M1'>1 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
  </model>
</world>
```
content.html:
Can we address that __model__ cannot be used in //model/pose[@relative_to]? Also, can the implicit model frame be referred to by its name if the referring entity is at the same level as the model? For example, is the following allowed?

<world name='w'>
  <model name='M1'/>
  <model name='M2'>
    <pose relative_to='M1'>1 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
  </model>
</world>

pullrequest.title: Update pose frame proposal to support //xyz[@expressed_in]

content.raw:
I believe by construction, setting `//model/pose[@relative_to="__model__"]` would create a graph cycle, no? That seems kinda implicit; I’d expect the same for stuff like `//link/pose[@relative_to=”<link name>”`.

If we do address this, I think it would belong in a more general section about the cycles themselves.

Regarding your other question: `M1` isn’t really tied to `__model__` \(at least w.r.t. this meta-proposal\); should we address that question outside of this PR? \(but we should def. address it\)
content.html:
I believe by construction, setting //model/pose[@relative_to="__model__"] would create a graph cycle, no? That seems kinda implicit; I’d expect the same for stuff like //link/pose[@relative_to=”<link name>”.

If we do address this, I think it would belong in a more general section about the cycles themselves.

Regarding your other question: M1 isn’t really tied to __model__ (at least w.r.t. this meta-proposal); should we address that question outside of this PR? (but we should def. address it)

pullrequest.title: Update pose frame proposal to support //xyz[@expressed_in]

content.raw: in this example, I don't think `//model/pose[@relative_to="__model__"]` would create a cycle, since the source node in the world's pose relative-to graph is named `__world__`. I would expect that to fail because no nodes in the graph are named `__model__`, but I wouldn't expect any cycles
content.html: in this example, I don't think //model/pose[@relative_to="__model__"] would create a cycle, since the source node in the world's pose relative-to graph is named __world__. I would expect that to fail because no nodes in the graph are named __model__, but I wouldn't expect any cycles

pullrequest.title: Update pose frame proposal to support //xyz[@expressed_in]

content.raw: Actually, perhaps we need language to distinguish `__model__` \(the “locally-scoped implicit model frame”\) from `<model name>` \(the “external-facing implicit model frame”\)?
content.html: Actually, perhaps we need language to distinguish __model__ (the “locally-scoped implicit model frame”) from <model name> (the “external-facing implicit model frame”)?

pullrequest.title: Update pose frame proposal to support //xyz[@expressed_in]

content.raw: :thumbsup:

pullrequest.title: Update pose frame proposal to support //xyz[@expressed_in]

content.raw:
> I believe by construction, setting //model/pose[@relative_to="__model__"] would create a graph cycle, no?

Fair point. I guess it'll be more relevant when nesting is involved. I'm okay with leaving it as is for this PR.

> Regarding your other question: M1 isn’t really tied to __model__ 

I brought it up because we're implying that `__model__` is the only way to refer to the implicit model frame. Maybe we can be more specific saying "This proposal suggests that the implicit model frame can be referred to by **the children of the model** using
the reserved name `__model__`.
content.html:
I believe by construction, setting //model/pose[@relative_to="model"] would create a graph cycle, no?

Fair point. I guess it'll be more relevant when nesting is involved. I'm okay with leaving it as is for this PR.

Regarding your other question: M1 isn’t really tied to model

I brought it up because we're implying that __model__ is the only way to refer to the implicit model frame. Maybe we can be more specific saying "This proposal suggests that the implicit model frame can be referred to by the children of the model using the reserved name __model__.
